text: hello everyone uh my name is Meg gotel I
have been a software developer for over
two decades and back in 2021 I found
myself in my first people management
role and as any new uh people manager I
had to learn a lot at the very beginning
uh how to give valuable feedback how to
to protect my team against looming
deadlines but I also found myself in a
bit of a somewhat unique situation which
is that half of my team was based in
Ukraine and the geopolitical situation
was changing at the time so in addition
to looming deadlines we had a looming
threat of the
invasion
and when this started to get to the
point where we actually felt that it was
very likely to happen I started looking
around online to try to find resources
for what was one supposed to do in this
kind of situation so I did some Google
searches and almost everything that I
came up with related to how to manage a
team during a war was all directed at
kind of top level management and huge
multinational organizations so it was
saying things like make sure that
payroll isn't disrupted and you know
organize uh extractions to move move
people and their families out of the
country and I was just a team lead you
know I have a half dozen people uh I'm
in another country uh these were
Consultants so I don't even have any
access to their payroll information at
all so what could I do as a lowly team
lead to help these people in this
incredibly complicated situation and
luckily I'm part of an international
organization of uh online expat women
and I had a friend who had been based in
Ethiopia when the Civil War broke out
there and she reached out to me and gave
me a couple of key pointers and those
ended up being incredibly useful because
they gave me a really basic foundation
for what we needed to do and the very
first thing probably goes without saying
but it was to reassure everyone on the
team that they were the most important
priority them their families they come
before work no matter what so yes we
have a big production deadline that's
coming but at the end of the day that's
not going to matter in that kind of
situation but also I needed to stress
that point to anyone outside of the team
and say you know we are going to need to
adjust our deadlines we're going to need
to you know build a little bit of slack
in here because yes if everything goes
to plan we're going to deliver roughly
around this period of time but that
could be seriously disrupted by what's
going
on the other thing that she told me was
to make sure that we talked about
everyone's plan lands
upfront uh so for each of we were having
regular one-on-one so for each of the
people who was in the country uh in the
weeks before the invasion we sat down
and we said okay what should the worst
happen what are you going to do are you
going to stay where you're at are you
going to move to a different part of the
country will you be able to leave uh so
we kind of went through and I took notes
and I had an idea of what everyone's
plan was going to be so then when the
worst inevitably did happen it turned
out to be extremely useful because
everything kind of just went on to
autopilot so I knew where everyone was
going to go I knew who was going to be
able to potentially be in touch who was
going to be moving so I might not hear
from them for a few days and not only
that but also I became kind of a hub of
information so other people you know who
aren't on our team but who work with our
team people who just know the situation
and are concerned they all wanted to
kind of know that everything was going
to be okay and they didn't know what was
going on so then I ended up being kind
of the person who could tell all those
other people oh well you know we they
have an idea of what's going on this
person is going here this person is
going here you know basically reassuring
everyone else who was concerned but
obviously didn't want to be disrupting
them by saying hey what's going on with
you so after the initial
Invasion we kind of settled back down
into okay we're in our our second phase
of of strangely New Normal uh but
another piece of advice I had given was
you know be aware that there are going
to be disruptions in uh network
connectivity in power uh they're not
going to be available all of the time
and there's a lot of things that we can
do as developers working kind of
offline but obviously this kind of
impacts how we meet and how we
collaborate so we kind of just had to
set a different tone for everything
which was that be in meetings if you can
and if you can't we'll figure out a way
to work around it so we'll do things
asynchronously uh we'll do a lot of
things kind
of offline or on slack or you know
building shared documents but not
necessarily being able to schedule
meetings because we kept finding that
okay we're going to have a design review
and the whole team's going to get
together and go through something and
inevitably something happens uh another
thing was just to kind of it it became a
really low barrier of Entry of you know
I'm not going to be able to attend the
standup today because I need to go to
shelter and so those were just little
messages that got sent and if they
didn't get sent we just assume the best
and find out later uh but it really kind
of changed the way we had been working
because we were a really collaborative
team so we had to find a way to move
those to more asynchronous uh models of
communication the other thing that I
realized that I needed to do was was to
find an outlet
so when you're in a high pressure
situation or a emotionally draining
situation it's important that you can
stay and be that kind of solid calm
presence that you need to be because
other people are expecting it from you
which means that you need to be able to
handle everything that's going on in
your own way so whether that's exercise
whether that's meeting up with a friend
to vent you need an outlet to be able to
process everything yourself
self the other thing that started to
happen was that things are changing all
the time so everything happened all at
once at the very beginning of the
situation but then things would start to
move in some things would happen in one
part of the country and some things
would happen in the other part of the
country and with everyone spread out it
was kind of hard to figure out who is
being impacted by what and as their
day-to-day manager it's my
responsibility to kind of understand
when these things are going to impact
those people when they're going to
impact the team and so I took it upon
myself to start following the news and
to make sure that I knew when something
was happening in one of the areas that
was going to impact us uh part of this
though is being a responsible media
consumer so knowing the biases in the
different news sources and following
them on a regular basis will help you to
understand so having a couple of
different sources that you can compare
and contrast and see how they handle
this situation differently uh
understanding that bias is important and
also recognize that there is some
sensationalism in the media so just
because media Outlets are saying oh this
is happening here and this is happening
here and this is happened so many times
in such and such a sequence of time you
have to remember that it doesn't
necessarily impact everyone in that area
and there's a lot of I wouldn't call it
over reporting but kind of
sensationalist reporting so you need to
also be able to pull kind of that aspect
out of it and understand what the
situation really is like for the people
on the
ground another key piece of this is that
it's not your employees responsibility
to be your new source so find ways to
stay up to date that don't require you
to have to ask them for information
because that is not their
job two years into this
we have kind of settled into a strange
new sense of normal we are actually able
to work very similar to the ways that we
did uh back during the pandemic so
everybody is remote in different
locations people are able to change
locations as they have the
need uh power generators and starlink
internet have pretty much solidified our
connectivity so we don't have the
meeting problems anymore but we're now
starting to face a new set of challenges
and I think it's kind of similar there
are a lot of parallels to the time that
we were all working during Co and one of
those is that we're starting to see
risks of burnout because work can become
a one sense of normaly in this really
really chaotic situation so when you
can't go on the same kinds of vacations
that you used to do or you may not be
able to go out as often as you did
before everything is different but being
able to work in the same way that you
are used to working brings this one
little sense of normaly and we've
started to see that sometimes that gets
carried a little bit too far and people
work too much because that is a safe
comfortable Zone uh one thing that comes
from one person working too much besides
that person's risk of burnout is also
that if they generate too much code
that's going to be a lot of pull
requests that everyone else has to then
review and you don't want everyone else
to end up having their entire job being
to review the poll request of the people
who are working overtime
so what we've been doing there is to try
to encourage people to do more training
to explore personal product projects and
kind of to do work adjacent things so
that if work is what's giving them that
kind of anchor in the storm they can
still do that but in ways that are a
little bit less
disruptive so I actually have been going
back and forth for a year trying to
decide whether or not I even wanted to
submit this
abstract uh part of that is because it's
not not their story isn't my story to
tell so I didn't want to feel like I was
capitalizing on something that happened
to other people but over time I started
to realize that even though their
stories aren't my story I have my own
story and I can tell my own story
because I own my own story and also I
thought back to those first days at the
beginning of the invasion when I was
looking for resources and I couldn't
find any and I sincerely hope that no
one else find find themselves in this
situation but since war is a reality I
hope that this will serve as a resource
to the people who come after me who
might need it so thank you for giving me
the platform to share that
[Applause]
